title: 109_s2205
content:
The Act is titled the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature are defined in the Act of 2006. The Commission refers to the Commission of Schools and Public Lands. Nonpreferential lease parcels are land parcels purchased by the Secretary for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. Preferential leaseholders are also defined in the Act. The Pierre Canal feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized in 1968. A preferential leaseholder is someone who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and unleased parcels are defined as land not under lease for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The State may accept parts of these features in "as is" condition. The State may agree to accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features in "as is" condition, along with any liabilities and responsibilities related to ownership, operation, and maintenance. The State will also act as the agent for the Secretary in administering purchase options for preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations will be binding upon the State. The State will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option extended to preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations will be binding upon the State, and any conveyance to the State will be subject to certain conditions and reservations. The State will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option extended to preferential leaseholders, subject to reservations and conditions specified in previous legislation. The value of the parcel determined under paragraph (4) minus ten percent of that value. Installment purchase option with 10 percent down payment and remaining balance payable over 30 years at 3 percent interest. For parcels under $10,000, cash purchase is required. Preferential leaseholders have 5 years to exercise their option. Leaseholders can continue leasing under existing terms until the deadline. Valuation based on fair market value for agricultural purposes. The preferential leaseholders have the option to continue leasing the parcel under the same terms. The value of the parcel is determined by fair market value for agricultural purposes. If the leaseholder fails to purchase the parcel within the specified period, the Secretary will offer to convey the parcel to the state. The Secretary will offer to convey parcels to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks if preferential leaseholders fail to purchase within the specified period. The land conveyed will be used for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury for the establishment of a trust fund to pay county taxes on the lands received by the State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Funds will be available to the State for a trust fund to pay county taxes on lands received by the State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Land exchanges may also occur with the concurrence of the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges with the Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Priority is given to exchanges with current lessees and adjoining landowners for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands prioritizes land exchanges with current lessees and adjoining landowners for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structures in land exchanges, and releases liability for damages except for acts of negligence. The United States is not liable for damages related to parcels under this Act, except for acts of negligence. No additional liability is added under the Federal Tort Claims Act. The Secretary must continue leasing preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels until conveyance. Parcel descriptions must be provided within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will transfer archeological collections to the South Dakota State Historical Society without cost. $750,000 is authorized for expenses incurred in implementing the Act. Authorization of $750,000 for expenses to implement the Act, including reimbursement for the Secretary, Commission, and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks.
